1158.08.text:
think of talent you could
imagine, he was fast,

1161.09.text:
he had great hands, he could
hit the ball either left hand

1164.69.text:
or right hand, he could throw
either left hand or right hand.

1167.82.text:
You know, he could eat, you
know, double cheeseburger,

1170.82.text:
and he looked like he had the
body of, you know, a Greek god.

1174.11.text:
He just had everything
going for him.

1175.76.text:
So you have one on one end and
the other was just an average,

1178.69.text:
good baseball player, but
average, not anywhere,

1181.15.text:
didn't look anywhere
near the same

1182.63.text:
as the other baseball player,
but the one thing he had

1185.38.text:
that the other guy didn't
is he had work ethic.

1188.42.text:
And this is-- as my,
you know, vantage point,

1193.02.text:
and I know both these
people, so if you look at it,

1198.53.text:
He went to the batting cages
and he religiously hit balls,

1201.79.text:
and he went after
it every single day.

1204.23.text:
He spent hour after
hour after hour

1206.54.text:
and he just dedicate
himself for the sport.

1208.97.text:
While the other person,
he practiced,

1213.10.text:
They both went on
to play college,

1216.44.text:
What ends up happening
is the one

1217.78.text:
that was very talented
eventually realized

1219.42.text:
that his talent couldn't
carry him,

1221.06.text:
and the same work ethic didn't
exist that the other player had.

1223.84.text:
And when it became time to
move on to that next level,

1226.33.text:
the very talented player was
no better than the other guy,

1229.14.text:
[inaudible] he spent
so much time becoming

1231.60.text: so refined at his skill set.

1234.27.text:
And eventually, talent
runs out without hard work.

1237.78.text:
They-- As I look at this,
both these gentlemen,

1239.96.text:
one went on to play in the
bigs, and-- the big leagues,

1242.91.text:
and played major league baseball
for a quite a long time.

1246.00.text:
The other one ended
up, you know,

1247.47.text:
kind of after college baseball,
ended up not playing anymore.

1252.18.text:
So it kind of gives you
two different analogies

1254.56.text:
as what hard work
can do, which--

1256.50.text:
kind of I'm going to jump down
to kind of this "Growth Mindset"

1258.96.text:
by Carol Dweck, which is
something I would encourage

1263.89.text:
to read a book called
"Growth Mindset".

1266.25.text: There's a TED talk about it.

1268.07.text:
It's actually indirectly
about Carol Dweck.

1271.34.text:
But nevertheless,
it's till a good read.

1275.62.text:
What it basically talks
about and what her thesis is,

1279.42.text:
There's a fixed mindset
and a growth mindset.

1282.17.text:
And the fixed mindset
really basically says,

1284.31.text:
you're only as good with what
you've been endowed with.

1286.80.text: So if I have been endowed with,

1288.56.text:
let's say for example using
my same analogy on baseball,

1292.09.text:
I'm really, really good at
hitting the ball left handed

1294.87.text:
and that's what I've
been endowed with.

1297.43.text:
And what the mentality
[inaudible] the fixed mindset

1299.64.text:
is, you really can't
get much better

1303.56.text:
Conversely, the growth mindset
would suggest that, "Hey,

1306.71.text:
I've been given-- I have
some talent, but I can take

1309.79.text:
that talent and I can expound
upon that by hard work,

1312.38.text:
by discipline, by being
smart about my training."

1315.31.text:
And so the same can
be said about business

1316.93.text:
and entrepreneurship
when we think about it

1322.43.text:
it's not always about
what you've been given,

1324.18.text:
it's about how you take
what you've been given

1327.12.text:
and it's having the
belief system

1328.35.text:
in yourself that
you can do that.

1330.68.text:
Everybody can get a
little bit better.

1332.73.text:
It's not just what
you've been given.

1334.65.text:
And we've been given
a different hand.

1336.18.text:
Everybody's been dealt
a different hand.

1337.69.text:
The question is, what are you
going to do with your hand?

1340.08.text:
How are you going
to take that hand

1341.52.text:
and expound upon it
and become better?

1343.90.text:
And that is a personal decision
that each one of you have

1346.26.text:
to make, is how do you do
the-- how do you get better,

1348.77.text:
how do you do more than
what you've been given.

1351.25.text:
And my-- I strongly
encourage you to do this,

1353.64.text:
which is never give
up, resistance truly is

1357.30.text:
to make you better, it's not to
prevent you from getting ahead,

1360.43.text:
and when you're uncomfortable,
that's actually a good place

1364.34.text:
to be, because it says
that you're growing

1366.46.text:
and you're learning, is when
we get really comfortable,

1368.84.text:
or become stagnant, and like
you don't want to be stagnant.

1372.14.text:
The worst thing in business is
to be comfortable and stagnant,

1374.96.text:
because there are
always people disrupting,

1376.78.text:
there are always
people coming after you.

1378.67.text:
And so being stagnant is
not a good place to be.

1381.62.text:
Constantly be trying to improve,
that's that growth mindset,

1384.54.text:
always be looking
ways to improve.

1386.31.text:
Take what you've been
given, expound upon it.

1388.82.text:
So that would be
the next principle.

1391.84.text:
There really isn't a
replacement for hard work.

1394.24.text:
I guess in conclusion,
I like-- this is--

1398.96.text:
people judge success in all
different shapes or forms,

1402.15.text:
and I really like Ray
Dalio's definition of success.

And so for those who
don't know Ray Dalio,

1407.04.text: I'll give another book to read.

1412.05.text:
of the hedge fund called
Bridgewater and Associates.

1415.85.text:
It's the largest hedge fund
with assets on their management.

You can go to his

1421.64.text:
on his website, he has
something called principles.

1423.22.text:
You can download it, print

1426.66.text:
I call it the bible
for business.

1429.48.text:
I really love what
he has written here.

1431.91.text:
Basically, the ethos
of this come

1433.96.text: to when Ray had been asked--

1435.78.text:
and he talks about this in
the preface of principles.

1438.73.text:
Basically, people would

Why have you become

1443.25.text:

1446.17.text:
to him, and he outlined them

1450.03.text:
like 120 pages or

I mean, he spent a

but what he did was he
really provided the roadmap

And there's some-- you'd have

to see some of them may

1465.35.text:
some of it may not

1466.43.text:
but there are some really great

1470.93.text:
The-- And this is his definition

1474.24.text:
with more, which is
so what is success?

1476.66.text:
I believe there's nothing more
than getting what you want,

1479.81.text: and that is up for you--

1480.83.text:
and that is up to you to
decide what it is for you.

1484.35.text:
I don't care whether it's
being a master of the universe,

1486.58.text:
a couch potato, or anything
else, I really don't.

1489.34.text:
What is essential is that you
are clear about what you want,

1491.90.text:
and then you figure
out how to get it.

1494.48.text:
And that is the million
dollar question,

1497.83.text:
and literally it is a
million dollar question,

1499.94.text:
to figure out what it
is you really want.
